intro: Poranthera microphylla var. drummondii, commonly known as Drummond's sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family, characterized by its hairy stems and showy blue or violet flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, sandy soils and is adapted to arid environments. It produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds. Its botanical features make it well-suited for xeriscaping and ecological restoration projects in desert regions.
